There’s another side to this extremist posture, however, where all ideas, images and poses are reduced to empty entertainment. The result is apathy, and vulgar nihilism. As a culture, we don’t recognize the reality of fiction, though we are utterly swept up in the compulsions of our narratives, while at the same time unwilling to commit entirely to anything with an act greater than a tweet, even for the things that we think are of utmost importance. It’s easier than challenging and possibly facing death as the repercussion of our actions, certainly easier than using our death for artistic purpose. How literally should we take Nietzsche, when he wrote ‘Of all that is written, I love only what a person has written with his own blood?’

There are many accounts of the day of his death. Henry Scott Stokes’, in The Life and Death of Yukio Mishima, is amongst the best at conveying the cinematic quality of what transpired. Stokes recounts Mishima meeting with four of his students, and their attempt to take General Mashita hostage at the Ichigaya base of the Jietai. First, they barricaded themselves in his office, and fought off several attempts on the part of confused unarmed officers to assess the situation and make them stop. The officers couldn’t seem to believe their sincerity, and shouted things such as ‘stop this play acting!’, despite the fact that the General was gagged and bound to a chair, or that Mishima was waving a sword around. Indeed, Mishima’s playing soldier had always had something of the theatrical to it, even though they were allowed military access. He was a celebrity. Most must have considered it an affectation.

__Simulation is infinitely more dangerous because it always leaves open to supposition that, above and beyond its object, law and order themselves might be nothing but simulation. […] Simulate a robbery in a large store: how to persuade security that it is a simulated robbery? To the established order they are always of the order of the real. Organize a fake holdup. Verify that your weapons are harmless, and take the most trustworthy hostage, so that no human life will be in danger (or one lapses into the criminal).

Even those present at the time had a hard time distinguishing fiction from reality. But the sword the Tatenokai brought with them was a real seventeenth-century blade, and wickedly sharp. The blood was real. Still, it seems more like performance art gone wrong than a serious coup d’etat. This is the more troubling dimension to Mishima’s ritual: it was a brutal imposition of idea upon the real. Of the different takes on Mishima’s suicide — political, a lover’s pact, a work of art, we should see all the above in some measure, because they are all of a piece. The romanticism of his younger years, already rife with bloody-minded undercurrent, expressed itself outwardly in politics, a theatre with real blades and real death, an attempt at reconciling fiction and reality, which is truly where the Romantic impulse originates. Writing was the first compensation, a compulsion driven by some need to find equilibrium. This sort of fixation in an artist always goes beyond mere vocation, a source of both pride and shame. He seemed to increasingly look down on it as his need to somehow enter a world forever cut off from him.

Mishima’s Dandyism, such as it was, was from a very early age fixated on the erotism of death. This underlying logic seems to run through much of Mishima’s fiction, that the embodiment of the highest virtue was an aestheticized death. To Mishima, there seems no distinction between the two, as both represented a vision — the most obvious example being the image of Saint Sebastian shot through with arrows, which he claims, by dissembling the truth through fiction in __Confessions of a Mask__, as the dawning of his sexuality. The fantasies of his childhood never stopped, they just became more elaborate. We can leap from this to his mythology of the Emperor as the external embodiment of his anti-metaphysic without skipping a beat, and so we may find an early hint here of what is both ambiguous and yet perplexingly literary about the course of his life, and especially the way it ended. Masks and fictional characters are alike in the manner that a relative lack of complexity renders them coherent.

By the mid-1990s, one of Bowie’s favourite interview topics was ritual sacrifice and the role of the body in art, so thematically, his shared obsessions with Mishima remained very real for him. The conceit of this 1995 album seems to — wittingly or unwittingly — react to a line of thought from Adorno, ‘Behind every work of art lies an uncommitted crime’. Bowie asks, ‘What if the crime is the art?’ Bowie had depicted the Minotaur in a few paintings for a 1994 theme exhibit in London (‘Minotaur Myths and Legends’), but he was a character within the album as well, the killer in his loosely fleshed out ‘hyperloop’, a peripheral figure and yet key to the central concept: through the sacrifice of the living body, the immortality of art is conferred.

This installation piece remains figurative as well as speculative, as Bowie was not the sort to break the fourth wall by actually killing for the sake of art. For all we know this hypothetical was never meant to be acted on, or maybe Bowie simply lost interest in the idea. However, before 25 November 1970, for all the extremes of Mishima’s nihilistic and then militaristic posturing — in fact, perhaps in part because of them — most of his friends and fans didn’t think he was the sort to enact his art in reality, either. Surely, they wouldn’t have let him and his Tatenokai march into a military base with a sword if they did. We may conclude that Mishima became trapped in his own myth, though that narrative only came about because of his being arrested by it in the first place, like a spider trapped in their own web.
